Patch Set 7:

Hi All,

Could you please review this design document and provide your comments if any.

Thanks,
Kumar.

Hi Priyatharshan, 

Can you use your full name here?

From https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages 

All commit messages must include a "Signed-off-by" line, which indicates that you the contributor have agreed to the Developer Certificate of Origin (see below). This line must include the full name you commonly use, often a given name and a family name or surname. (ok: Sam Samuelsson, Robert A. Heinlein; not ok: xXthorXx, Sam, RAH)

Thanks!

Hi, Thanks for the info.

But "Priyatharshan P" is my full name.

The problem is really more fundamental than 'single host' vs 'multi-host'.  The problem is anytime we want to activate a software update which could be applicable for multiple devices.

I don't think creating a new interface called 'biosUpdate' is the right approach because it doesn't solve the general problem.  BIOS is really specific to x86 architectures anyhow.
By Multiple devices do you mean Multiple CPLD's / Bridge IC's, etc in a single host?
VRs, CPLDs, GPUs, Intel MEs, IBM OCCs, even BMCs in some multi-BMC designs.  There are lots of cases where a single firmware image may be applicable to multiple devices in the system.

So there are lot of cases we are haiving muliple devices in the systems.One thought is we can have a JSON config file that describes the number of devices associated with the system.

A dafult JSON file will be provided in phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt, and the platform specific JSON file should be provided from receipe layer.

The sample config file will look something like below:

host1
{
   VR:3
   CPLD:2
   GPU:1
   Intel_ME:2
},
host2
{
   VR:2
   CPLD:1
   GPU:3
   Intel_ME:1
}
...

Kindly share your comments on this.

I would prefer if it were either based on Inventory or if the software update software made that determination, likely based on Inventory.

It isn't as simple as just "there are 2 CPLDs so any CPLD update can be applied anywhere".  There might be 2 CPLDs which serve a different purpose and the ExtendedVersion field is suppose to be used to make a determination as to which CPLDs an image might be appropriate for.  (CPLDs were used as an example here.)

Agree, we can make software-manager to determine all the available devices from inventory that needs firmware update. Currently, updating the design document which uses the inventory. Need clarifications considering couple of approaches.

1. Use of ExtendedVersion:
 a) How does the ExtendedVersion be used to determine which device needs an firmware update considering multiple device scenario.
 b) Could the ExtendedVersion value in MANIFEST file be mapped with inventory objects.
 c) Do we expect to update the firmware image for all the devices that matches the ExtendedVersion.
 d) Is the ExtendedVersion value in the MANIFEST file be factroy ship out or to be modified by the user before each update.

2. As an alternate, can create new interfaces for each of the object identified from the inventory. Then user can sets the new "biosUpdate" property to "true" for devices that needs firmware update. After successfull activation the image will be deleted at the end.
Is this a compile-time option, or how would the phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt app have access to this number to create the hostX d-bus interfaces?

This is the compile time option only. We have mentioned this OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES in the machine conf files for each platform. So All the application can access the OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES in the bb/bb.append files. OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES default value is "0" for single host.

Could a system support a different number of host instances? Are there any concerns that for example there is a meta-yosemitev2 configuration with 2 hosts and one with 4 hosts, or if in the future more host instances are supported?
Yes , the system will support for a different number of host instances.

I don't think that we should create software/<entity> subdirectories unless we get sign-off from the Redfish implementation.  No other firmware update subsystems have done this and the Redfish / WebUI code doesn't know to interrogate subdirectories.

What specifically is solved by having a subdirectory?  Can that be solved by an association instead?
If they don't, should the Redfish API return an error because nothing was updated, or success and the user can figure out themselves?
Yes, If no host is selected for bios update, The code will throw "No host is added for update".

Again, this is a more fundamental problem.

The image should really only be deleted when "there are no more entities for which this image could be applied but is not yet applied".  This is really an implementation flaw in the single-host implementation and not an interface change.

With openbmc adopting Redfish, we'll need this property to be available in the Redfish schema. Are there any reasons not to use the BiosUpdate value you list below? (you mentioned that it could be considered). Perhaps also you could investigate to see if the DMTF has already solved how to select resources for parallel updates.
Since this is mentioned to support firmware other than BIOS we might want another file name / title.  Not sure what though.
suggest being consistent with capitalization here: BIOS
EM may or may not be where all inventory lives.  Avoid referencing EM specifically since that is an implementation of *some* inventory objects.

I'm not following what this is referring to.  I don't find anything in phosphor-dbus-interfaces having a property Class.  If you're proposing something new it needs to be documented there as well.  If you're using something that EM is providing due to some JSON files, we need to get that documented.

I have created a WIP patch for this approach2 with the below link:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt/+/37448

Kindly review this doc and share your thoughts of both approaches.

There are concerns listed in the original doc where this new property to select which instance to update does not map to redfish. The direction is to get all the user interfaces into redfish instead of the custom REST apis.
I don't understand this sentence.  The user should not be responsible for knowing which devices a firmware image can apply to.  Is that what you're suggesting?

@Adriana, You already suggested this new property to select which instance to update does not map to redfish. But I think the user should have the knowledge or should select which are the devices are getting updated.Any thoughts?
@Adriana, Could you please update on the above.

> The user should not be responsible for knowing which devices a firmware image can apply to.  Is that what you're suggesting?

What I understand is that this doc is trying to solve how to selectively update a subset of items, in this case the bios, by allowing the user to select which of the multiple bios instances should be updated and leaving the other bios instances untouched.

> You already suggested this new property to select which instance to update does not map to redfish. But I think the user should have the knowledge or should select which are the devices are getting updated

I'm just pointing out that any interface or property should be mapped to redfish, since that's what bmcweb and openbmc in general supports as an external interface.
@Adriana, are you ok with this approach?  I'd tend to prefer we improve Activation to handle multiple items, but I don't have a good way to do it.

Agree that we should try to fit this in the current Activation interface. Maybe some way via expanding the inventory associations, i think it's been discussed to use the inventory items as triggers. Need to think about this some more.

I don't like this initial proposal but I think it is almost workable.

1. Software is intended to be a very generic name and not specific to "firmware".  I don't see any reason to restrict the multi-item update process to "firmware" either by calling it "fw update".

2. What we're really doing here is extending Activation so that the Activation is applied across a set of Inventory items.  I would suggest instead we create an interface maybe called ActivationItems (Elements?) which has a property : Items type=array<object_path> and maybe a method : AddItem(object_path).  The object_paths will reference the Inventory item to be updated.  When the activation is done the the update code will apply to all the applicable Inventory objects in the Items array.  We may need a signal for failed updates, especially in the case where the update image does not apply to the item.

Ideally, I'd like to see Activation refactored in a way where it can support a direct relationship between the SoftwareVersion and the Inventory item(s) to be updated.  I think there are some cases where you'll want to do an update to all the devices and some cases where you'll want to do the update one at a time but still without deleting the update at the end.  In my mind, the default behavior of the system should be to *not* delete an update for which there still exists an Inventory item that the update *could* apply to, unless the user explicitly Delete's the update.
That, to me, is a pretty minor disadvantage.  Isn't there anything we can do to fix it?
I'm not convinced I understand this section.  Is this a requirement or a design or just some background?
This is the requirement to get the devices/hosts list from the BMC inventory.

"Software manager" isn't a term that has been defined up to this point.  There is "ImageManager" in the original design doc.  Is this what you are referring to?  Why is the "ImageManager" responsible for interacting with the whole Inventory space?  Need some more words here.
Sotware manager is repo name. I am referring to ItemUpdater. ItemUpdater will use both inventory and entity-manager to get the devices/hosts list.
Does this mean a single one or a new one per device/update type?
new single instance generic for all image types.
'Host' and not "HOST".  It isn't an acronym.
Please update this section to incorporate the Compatibility design.  I would expect something like "Compatible" being the data entry in the manifest.

No.  Let's rely on the manifest.

We need these to be specific to the device being updated.  There are many different CPLD chip models and a huge number of purposes of those CPLDs in a server.  There is no way to take an arbitrary image named "CPLD" and know if it goes on a particular device.

The same goes for BIOS, VR, BIC, ME...
I'm not sure this is a useful section.  These are implementation-specific decisions, so leave it to the implementation of an ItemUpdater to figure it out.
I assume this is related to the Compatible interface? https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/49210
Yes. This is related to Compatible interface.
I'm pretty sure markdown backticks need to be at the beginning of the line and not indented.

If we are launching updates via service files, how do we track completion and report error status?

Where are you expecting the code for all this to live?

Tracking - New D-bus property called completionPercent or isCompleted flag to track the completion status. 

Will explore an alternate for service file logic.
How did the name 'host' come to be here?  What is the relationship between the Activation path names and the proposed systemd service?
Ack. This flash takes care of host image update. Will remove the host since BMC updater not used service file.
Please don't turn service files into another scripting language.
Strike this concept.  There is no value in it.
There is, at a minimum, incorrect verb tense somewhere here.  I don't know what this sentence is suggesting because depending on which verbs I correct I get a different meaning.

Ack. If the field "TargetHosts" is NOT present in the MANIFEST file, then the update is performed in all devices/hosts identified by the ItemUpdater, then the image is removed from disk.

Will change this in the doc.
Hopefully only for un-applied images, right?
What code is doing the listening here?  This paragraph isn't obvious what it is requiring to be done.
Host ItemUpdater code doing to watch/listening if user removes the image manually, we need to remove the object path, clean flags.
Please use proper Compatible strings for this identification.

Hi All, 

 Could you please review this design and provide your comments if any or provide your approval.

Thanks,
Kumar.
